captions.text:
I did consider playing Battlefield 6. &quot;Hey, 
Yahtzee, why don&#39;t you play Battlefield 6?&quot;

a contemporary said to me. &quot;It&#39;s actually 
good!&quot; &quot;Really, contemporary?&quot; I asked. &quot;It

has a well-designed single-player campaign with 
a compelling story?&quot; &quot;Errrrrrrr, you know what?

Never mind; as you were.&quot; Out of curiosity, 
I opened the Battlefield 6 Wikipedia page,

scrolled down to the plot summary, noticed 
the phrase &quot;private military company,&quot; and

then I closed the Battlefield 6 Wikipedia 
page. Happily, I also discovered there was

a third Little Nightmares game just come out, 
mind-blowingly titled Little Nightmares 3.

Which not only would be more appropriate for 
October but also seemed to be getting panned

in the Steam reviews. &quot;Oh boy, I need to play 
this,” I said to myself. “I&#39;ll probably fucking

hate it. What fun I&#39;ll have.” What the fuck else 
was there left to do with the Little Nightmares

concept? Linear Limbo-style puzzle platformer 
about frightened child scampering around huge,

bleak world just barely escaping from 
misshapen nightmare grown-ups resembling

clumsily reupholstered leather furniture, and 
the plot is &quot;it&#39;s a nightmare&quot; and therefore

doesn&#39;t have to make sense. We had that figured 
out by the title screen of Little Nightmares 2.

Explain yourself, developer of Little Nightmares 
Tarsier Studios. &quot;Who are you talking to,

Yahtz?&quot; What? Tarsier Studios? But if you&#39;re 
over there, who&#39;s developing Little Nightmares

3? Who on earth would be so wretched as to take 
someone else&#39;s fully milked IP and try to wring

another game out of it? &quot;Hello!&quot; Supermassive 
Games! I might&#39;ve known. What&#39;re you doing

here? &quot;Eh. Got bored of making crushingly dull 
linear horror games. Thought we&#39;d mix things up

by making a crushingly dull linear horror game 
that doesn&#39;t star B-list Hollywood actors.&quot; And

Supermassive wouldn&#39;t be Supermassive if they 
weren&#39;t crowbarring blisteringly unnecessary

multiplayer modes into their shit, so Little 
Nightmares 3&#39;s gimmick is that it&#39;s two-player

co-op. And permit me to now list every example 
of a successful multiplayer-focused sequel to

a previously single-player-focused franchise. 
&quot;I&#39;d rather you didn&#39;t, Yahtz.&quot; Don&#39;t worry,

it won&#39;t take long. In fact, I already did it 
in the pause after my previous sentence. Would

you also like me to list every time an atmospheric 
narrative horror game has been made more effective

by co-op gameplay? &quot;I&#39;m not sure we have time, 
Yahtz.&quot; WELL, I&#39;VE GOT GOOD NEWS FOR YOU.

I&#39;m not saying an innovator couldn&#39;t come along 
and reverse these trends, but Little Nightmares

3 ain&#39;t it, me ducks. Sadly, my homunculus was 
out getting his teeth-whitening procedure done,

but the game does let you play single player 
with an AI partner. And therefore misses out

even on the grudging respect I extend to Split 
Fiction and It Takes Two for insisting upon

the two-player dynamic, and it means instead of 
playing a boring horror game that routinely sucks

all the tension out of itself by having every 
set piece kill you over and over again until

you figure out the precise sequence of actions 
required to evade whatever grinning metaphor

for societal decay is chasing you this time, 
you now have to do all of that while ensuring

a fucking AI companion is keeping up so the 
two of you can open the inevitable co-op game

very heavy two-person doors before a half-melted 
Margaret Thatcher Spitting Image puppet can run

up and bite off all your union benefits. And 
you do have to rely on the other dude &#39;cause

it&#39;s doing the It Takes Two coordination thing: 
one player gets the melee weapon and the other

gets the ranged weapon and both are needed at 
various times to neutralize threats and puzzles.

But every now and again, the AI partner just 
fucks it up—misses the shot or doesn&#39;t get

away from the chasey thing in time—and I have to 
reload a save. Maybe they thought it&#39;d recreate

the co-op experience more authentically if the 
AI partner was as fallible as us puny humans,

but this is basically the game hitting itself 
in the face with a hammer and then calling me

the asshole for not telling it to stop. 
There&#39;s almost no visual consistency when

it comes to what you&#39;re supposed to interact 
with; climbable things and smashable things

will frequently be indistinguishable from that 
which can&#39;t be climbed and shuns the smash. But

Supermassive did a pretty admirable job of 
imitating the Little Nightmares house style,

so if you take every negative thing I said about 
Little Nightmares 2 and add the phrase &quot;and then

there&#39;s this asshole,&quot; we can probably knock 
off from the review early. The story involves

Twat A and Twat B using magic mirrors to teleport 
between various nightmare set pieces so the game&#39;s

world has even less sense of coherent geography 
than ever. There&#39;s a bit with a giant evil baby;

there&#39;s a bit in an evil carnival; there&#39;s a 
bit in an evil office building being chased

by a giant monstrous middle manager who 
looks distractingly like Rupert Murdoch.

But I&#39;d say the defining moment came early on 
when I was navigating a—brace yourself—darkened

room in a run-down building when suddenly, Melinoë 
from Hades 2 appeared and offered me one of three

boons, including a 10% increased resistance to 
gnawing my own tits off from boredom, and then

I shook myself and realized that hadn&#39;t happened 
at all and I was still in the gloomy, run-down

room. &quot;Fuck a duck,&quot; I said. &quot;Did I just literally 
fall asleep playing this game? And briefly dream

about playing a better game?&quot; No, seriously, I 
actually did. It&#39;s completely unprecedented. But

what better evidence for the utter and complete 
lack of appeal in a horror game whose contextless

horror creates zero sense of investment or lasting 
dread and which obliterates what little visceral

horror it creates in the moment with repeated 
restarts? &quot;Not to mention evidence that you

should probably double-check your retirement 
plan, Yahtz.&quot; Oh, fuck off, viewer. Whoops,

I meant to say, &quot;Please like and subscribe 
to the channel.&quot; Anyway, I discovered in what

I will laughingly call my &quot;research&quot; for 
this game that original Little Nightmares

developer Tarsier Studios has a demo out on 
Steam Next Fest for their new game, Reanimal.

And I was like, &quot;Great, classic narrative, 
original developer leaves their burnt-out IP

behind, leaving their publisher to get some other 
poor sucker to milk the floppy, deflated udders

of what was once a cow before its skeleton was 
removed while they move on to exciting pastures

new. Tell me about Reanimal, Tarsier Studios.&quot; 
&quot;Well, it&#39;s a linear horror game in which you and

a co-op partner play small children navigating 
a scary world full of monstrous adults—&quot; Can I

stop you there, Tarsier Studios, and interject 
with: what the odorously prolapsing fuck? It

plays identically to Little Nightmares 3. It&#39;s 
even got that thing where it lets you pick what

scary mask your character wears and then looks at 
you in smiling, unblinking lack of comprehension

as you very conspicuously fail to give a shit. 
It&#39;s maybe got a touch more creativity; I enjoyed

the bit where you pull a floppy man out of a 
toilet, but that was mainly from the empowering

dad energy I get from successfully clearing 
blockages in pipework. Why on earth would you

break off from your established, no longer fresh 
IP and then go off and make something exactly like

it? That&#39;s like divorcing your spouse so you 
can marry your spouse wearing a different hat.
